analyzed: vibhaṅga
translated: The Vibhanga

original: Satipaṭṭhānavibhaṅga
analyzed: sati paṭṭhāna vibhaṅga
translated: The Vibhanga on the Establishments of Mindfulness

original: 1. Suttantabhājanīya
analyzed: suttanta bhājanīya
translated: The Suttas in the Mode of Questions

original: Cattāro satipaṭṭhānā—
analyzed: cattāro sati paṭṭhānā
translated: The four establishments of mindfulness:

original: idha bhikkhu ajjhattaṁ kāye kāyānupassī viharati bahiddhā kāye kāyānupassī viharati
analyzed: idha bhikkhu ajjhattam kāye kāya anupassī viharati bahiddhā kāye kāya anupassī viharati
translated: Here a monk, contemplating impermanence internally in the body, dwells contemplating the body; contemplating impermanence externally in the body, he dwells contemplating the body;

original: ajjhattabahiddhā kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ,
analyzed: ajjhatta bahiddhā kāye kāya anupassī viharati ātāpī sampajānaḥ satimā vineyya loke abhijjhā domanassa
translated: contemplating impermanence internally and externally in the body, he dwells contemplating the body—ardent, clearly comprehending, and mindful, having removed covetousness and displeasure in regard to the world.

original: ajjhattaṁ vedanāsu vedanānupassī viharati bahiddhā vedanāsu vedanānupassī viharati
analyzed: ajjhattam vedanāsu vedanā anupassī viharati bahiddhā vedanāsu vedanā anupassī viharati
translated: Contemplating impermanence internally in feelings, he dwells contemplating feelings; contemplating impermanence externally in feelings, he dwells contemplating feelings;

original: ajjhattabahiddhā vedanāsu vedanānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke
analyzed: ajjhatta bahiddhā vedanāsu vedanā anupassī viharati ātāpī sampajānaḥ satimā vineyya loke
translated: contemplating impermanence internally and externally in feelings, he dwells contemplating feelings—ardent, clearly comprehending, and mindful, having removed covetousness and displeasure in regard to the world.

original: abhijjhādomanassaṁ, ajjhattaṁ citte cittānupassī viharati bahiddhā citte cittānupassī
analyzed: abhijjhā domanassa ajjhattam citte citta anupassī viharati bahiddhā citte citta anupassī
translated: Contemplating impermanence internally in the mind, he dwells contemplating the mind; contemplating impermanence externally in the mind, he dwells contemplating the mind;

original: viharati ajjhattabahiddhā citte cittānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya
analyzed: viharati ajjhatta bahiddhā citte citta anupassī viharati ātāpī sampajānaḥ satimā vineyya
translated: contemplating impermanence internally and externally in the mind, he dwells contemplating the mind—ardent, clearly comprehending, and mindful, having removed covetousness and displeasure in regard to the world.

original: loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ, ajjhattaṁ dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati bahiddhā dhammesu
analyzed: loke abhijjhā domanassaḥ ajjhattam dhammesu dhamma anupassī viharati bahiddhā dhammesu
translated: Contemplating impermanence internally in dharmas, he dwells contemplating dharmas; contemplating impermanence externally in dharmas, he dwells contemplating dharmas;

original: dhammānupassī viharati ajjhattabahiddhā dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno
analyzed: dhamma anupassī viharati ajjhatta bahiddhā dhammesu dhamma anupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno
translated: He abides contemplating mind as mind internally, he abides contemplating mind as mind externally, he abides contemplating mind as mind both internally and externally.

original: satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ.
analyzed: satimā vineyya loke abhijjhā domanassa
translated: He abides contemplating in mind its arising factors, or he abides contemplating in mind its vanishing factors, or he abides contemplating in mind both its arising and vanishing factors.

original: 1.1. Kāyānupassanāniddesa
analyzed: kāya anupassanā niddesa
translated: .. The Description of Contemplation of the Body

original: Kathañca bhikkhu ajjhattaṁ kāye kāyānupassī viharati?
analyzed: kathaṃca bhikkhu ajjhattam kāye kāya anupassī viharati
translated: And how does a bhikkhu abide contemplating the body as a body?

original: Idha bhikkhu ajjhattaṁ kāyaṁ uddhaṁ pādatalā adho kesamatthakā tacapariyantaṁ pūraṁ nānappakārassa asucino paccavekkhati—🔽“atthi imasmiṁ kāye kesā lomā nakhā dantā taco, maṁsaṁ nhāru aṭṭhi aṭṭhimiñjaṁ vakkaṁ,
analyzed: idha bhikkhu ajjhattam kāyam uddham pāda talāḥ adhas kesamatthakā taca pariyantam pūram nānappakārassa asucino paccavekkhati  atthi imasmin kāye kesāḥ lomā nakhāḥ dantāḥ tacaḥ masam nhāru aṭṭhi aṭṭhimiñjam vakka
translated: Here a bhikkhu, gone to the forest or to the root of a tree or to an empty place, sits down; having folded his legs crosswise, set his body erect, and established mindfulness in front of him, ever mindful he breathes in, mindful he breathes out.

original: hadayaṁ yakanaṁ kilomakaṁ pihakaṁ papphāsaṁ, antaṁ antaguṇaṁ udariyaṁ karīsaṁ, pittaṁ🔽semhaṁ pubbo lohitaṁ sedo medo, assu vasā kheḷo siṅghāṇikā lasikā muttan”ti.
analyzed: hadayam yakanam kilomakam pihakam papphāsa antam antaguṇam udariyam karīsa pitta  semham pubbaḥ lohitam sedaḥ medaḥ assu vasā kheḷaḥ siṅghāṇikā lasikā muttanti
translated: Breathing in long, he knows “I breathe in long”; or breathing out long, he knows “I breathe out long. ” Breathing in short, he knows “I breathe in short”; or breathing out short, he knows “I breathe out short. ”

original: So taṁ nimittaṁ āsevati bhāveti bahulīkaroti, svāvatthitaṁ vavatthapeti.
analyzed: saḥ tam nimittam āsevati bhāveti bahulīkaroti su āvatthitam vavatthapeti
translated: He trains thus: experiencing the whole body I shall breathe in, thus he trains; experiencing the whole body I shall breathe out, thus he trains;🔽He trains thus: making the bodily process calm I shall breathe in, thus he trains; making the bodily process calm I shall breathe out, thus he trains.

original: So taṁ nimittaṁ āsevitvā bhāvetvā bahulīkaritvā svāvatthitaṁ vavatthapetvā bahiddhā kāye cittaṁ upasaṁharati.
analyzed: saḥ tam nimittam āsevitvā bhāvetvā bahulīkaritvā su āvatthitam vavatthapetvā bahiddhā kāye cittam upasaharati
translated: After cultivating that sign, after developing it, after making it his vehicle, after making it his basis, after making it his resort, after making it his ground, he directs his mind to the perception of the external earth kasiṇa.

original: Kathañca bhikkhu bahiddhā kāye kāyānupassī viharati?
analyzed: kathañca bhikkhu bahiddhā kāye kāya anupassī viharati
translated: And how does a bhikkhu abide contemplating the body as a body externally?

original: Idha bhikkhu bahiddhā kāyaṁ uddhaṁ pādatalā adho kesamatthakā tacapariyantaṁ pūraṁ nānappakārassa asucino paccavekkhati—🔽“atthissa kāye kesā lomā nakhā dantā taco, maṁsaṁ nhāru aṭṭhi aṭṭhimiñjaṁ vakkaṁ,🔽hadayaṁ yakanaṁ kilomakaṁ pihakaṁ papphāsaṁ, antaṁ antaguṇaṁ udariyaṁ karīsaṁ, pittaṁ
analyzed: idha bhikkhu bahiddhā kāyam uddham pāda talā adho kesamatthakā taca pariyantam pūram nānappakārassa asucino paccavekkhati  atthissa kāye kesāḥ lomā nakhāḥ dantāḥ tacaḥ masam nhāru aṭṭhi aṭṭhimiñjam vakka  hadayam yakanam kilomakam pihakam papphāsa antam antaguṇam udariyam karīsa pitta
translated: Here a bhikkhu reflects upon and considers that external body as full of many kinds of impurities in this way:

original: semhaṁ pubbo lohitaṁ sedo medo, assu vasā kheḷo siṅghāṇikā lasikā muttan”ti.
analyzed: semham pubbaḥ lohitam sedaḥ medaḥ assu vasā kheḷaḥ siṅghāṇikā lasikā muttanti
translated: “In his body there are head hairs, body hairs, nails, teeth, skin, flesh, sinews, bones, bone marrow, kidney, heart, liver, midriff, spleen, lungs, intestines, mesentery, contents of the stomach, feces, bile, phlegm, pus, blood, sweat, fat, tears, grease, saliva, snot, oil that moistens the joints, and urine.”

original: So taṁ nimittaṁ āsevati bhāveti bahulīkaroti, svāvatthitaṁ vavatthapeti.
analyzed: saḥ tam nimittam āsevati bhāveti bahulīkaroti su āvatthitam vavatthapeti
translated: He cultivates that sign, develops it, and repeatedly practices it.

original: So taṁ nimittaṁ āsevitvā bhāvetvā bahulīkaritvā svāvatthitaṁ vavatthapetvā ajjhattabahiddhā kāye cittaṁ upasaṁharati.
analyzed: saḥ tam nimittam āsevitvā bhāvetvā bahulīkaritvā su āvatthitam vavatthapetvā ajjhatta bahiddhā kāye cittam upasaharati
translated: He keeps pursuing that sign, develops it, and frequently dwells in it.

original: Kathañca bhikkhu ajjhattabahiddhā kāye kāyānupassī viharati?
analyzed: kathañca bhikkhu ajjhatta bahiddhā kāye kāya anupassī viharati
translated: And how does a monk abide contemplating the body as a body?

original: Idha bhikkhu ajjhattabahiddhā kāyaṁ uddhaṁ pādatalā adho kesamatthakā tacapariyantaṁ pūraṁ nānappakārassa asucino paccavekkhati—
analyzed: idha bhikkhu ajjhatta bahiddhā kāyam uddham pāda talāḥ adhas kesamatthakā taca pariyantam pūram nānappakārassa asucino paccavekkhati
translated: Here a monk having some aspect of his own body—from the soles of the feet upwards, or from the top of the head downwards, enclosed by skin and full of manifold impurities—contemplates the body.

original: “atthi imasmiṁ kāye kesā lomā nakhā dantā taco, maṁsaṁ nhāru aṭṭhi aṭṭhimiñjaṁ vakkaṁ,
analyzed: atthi imasmin kāye kesāḥ lomā nakhāḥ dantāḥ tacaḥ masam nhāru aṭṭhi aṭṭhimiñjam vakka
translated: “In this body there are head hairs, body hairs, nails, teeth, skin, flesh, sinews, bones, bone marrow, kidney,

original: hadayaṁ yakanaṁ kilomakaṁ pihakaṁ papphāsaṁ, antaṁ antaguṇaṁ udariyaṁ karīsaṁ, pittaṁ
analyzed: hadayam yakanam kilomakam pihakam papphāsa antam antaguṇam udariyam karīsa pitta
translated: heart, liver, pleura, spleen, lungs, intestines, mesentery, contents of the stomach, feces, bile,

original: semhaṁ pubbo lohitaṁ sedo medo, assu vasā kheḷo siṅghāṇikā lasikā muttan”ti.
analyzed: semham pubbaḥ lohitam sedaḥ medaḥ assu vasā kheḷaḥ siṅghāṇikā lasikā muttanti
translated: phlegm, pus, blood, sweat, fat, tears, grease, saliva, snot, synovic fluid, urine.”

original: Evaṁ bhikkhu ajjhattabahiddhā kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ.
analyzed: evam bhikkhu ajjhatta bahiddhā kāye kāya anupassī viharati ātāpī sampajānaḥ satimā vineyya loke abhijjhā domanassa
translated: Thus a monk abides contemplating the body as a body internally, externally, and both internally and externally.

original: “Anupassī”ti.
analyzed: anupassi iti
translated: “Contemplating” means:

original: Tattha katamā anupassanā?🔽Yā paññā pajānanā …pe… amoho dhammavicayo sammādiṭṭhi—
analyzed: tattha katamā anupassanā  yā paññā pajānanā pe amoho dhammavicayo sammādiṭṭhi
translated: Herein, what is contemplation?

original: ayaṁ vuccati “anupassanā”.
analyzed: ayam vuccati anupassanā
translated: That which is understanding, the act of understanding … the act of fathoming, penetrating, wisely fathoming, wisely penetrating, wisely knowing, wisely fathoming, wisely penetrating, is called ‘contemplation’.

original: Imāya anupassanāya upeto hoti samupeto upāgato samupāgato upapanno sampanno samannāgato.
analyzed: imāya anupassanāya upetaḥ hoti samupetaḥ upāgataḥ samupāgataḥ upapannaḥ sampannaḥ samannāgataḥ
translated: He is provided with, furnished with, supplied with, possessed of, endowed with this contemplation.

original: Tena vuccati “anupassī”ti.
analyzed: tena vuccati anupassī iti
translated: Hence ‘contemplating’ is said.

original: “Viharatī”ti.
analyzed: viharati iti
translated: ‘Dwells’ :

original: Iriyati vattati pāleti yapeti yāpeti carati viharati.
analyzed: iriyati vattati pāleti yapeti yāpeti carati viharati
translated: he moves, he behaves, he lives, he dwells, he exists.

original: Tena vuccati “viharatī”ti.
analyzed: tena vuccati viharati iti
translated: Hence ‘dwells’ is said.

original: “Ātāpī”ti.
analyzed: ātāpi iti
translated: ‘Ardent’:

original: Tattha katamo ātāpo?🔽Yo cetasiko vīriyārambho …pe… sammāvāyāmo—
analyzed: tattha katamaḥ ātāpaḥ  yaḥ cetasikaḥ vīriya ārambho pe sammāvāyāmo
translated: Herein, what is ardour?

original: ayaṁ vuccati “ātāpo”.
analyzed: ayam vuccati ātāpo
translated: That which is the mental factor of instigation, the mental factor of exertion, the mental factor of endeavour, the mental factor of energy, the mental factor of exertion of energy, the mental factor of endeavour of energy, the mental factor of striving, the mental factor of exertion of striving, the mental factor of endeavour of striving, right endeavour, is called ‘ardour’.

original: Iminā ātāpena upeto hoti samupeto upāgato samupāgato upapanno sampanno samannāgato.
analyzed: iminā ātāpena upetaḥ hoti samupetaḥ upāgataḥ samupāgataḥ upapanno sampanno samannāgato
translated: He is provided with, furnished with, supplied with, possessed of, endowed with this ardour.

original: Tena vuccati “ātāpī”ti.
analyzed: tena vuccati ātāpī iti
translated: Hence ‘ardent’ is said.

original: “Sampajāno”ti.
analyzed: sampajānoti
translated: ‘Clearly comprehending’:

original: Tattha katamaṁ sampajaññaṁ?🔽Yā paññā pajānanā …pe… amoho dhammavicayo sammādiṭṭhi—
analyzed: tattha katamam sampajañña  yā paññā pajānanā pe amoho dhammavicayo sammādiṭṭhi
translated: Herein, what is clear comprehension?

original: idaṁ vuccati “sampajaññaṁ”.
analyzed: idam vuccati sampajañña
translated: That which is understanding, the act of understanding … the act of fathoming, penetrating, wisely fathoming, wisely penetrating, wisely knowing, wisely fathoming, wisely penetrating, is called ‘clear comprehension’.

original: Iminā sampajaññena upeto hoti samupeto upāgato samupāgato upapanno sampanno samannāgato.
analyzed: iminā sampajaññena upetaḥ hoti samupetaḥ upāgataḥ samupāgataḥ upapannaḥ sampannaḥ samannāgato
translated: He is endowed with, provided with, possessed of, united with this clear comprehension.

original: Tena vuccati “sampajāno”ti.
analyzed: tena vuccati sampajānoti
translated: That is why ‘clearly comprehending’ is said.

original: “Satimā”ti.
analyzed: satimā ati
translated: Mindful:

original: Tattha katamā sati?
analyzed: tattha katamā sati
translated: Herein, what is mindfulness?

original: Yā sati anussati …pe… sammāsati—
analyzed: yā sati anussati pe sammā sati
translated: It is mindfulness …

original: ayaṁ vuccati “sati”.
analyzed: ayam vuccati sati
translated: This is called ‘mindfulness’.

original: Imāya satiyā upeto hoti samupeto upāgato samupāgato upapanno sampanno samannāgato.
analyzed: imāya satiyā upetaḥ hoti samupetaḥ upāgataḥ samupāgataḥ upapannaḥ sampanno samannāgataḥ
translated: He is endowed with, provided with, possessed of, united with this mindfulness.

original: Tena vuccati “satimā”ti.
analyzed: tena vuccati satimā iti
translated: That is why ‘mindful’ is said.

original: “Vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassan”ti.
analyzed: vineyya loke abhijjhā domanassanti
translated: Having put aside greed and sorrow regarding the world:

original: Tattha katamo loko?
analyzed: tattha katamaḥ loko
translated: Herein, what is the world?

original: Sveva kāyo loko.
analyzed: su eva kāyaḥ
translated: This body is the world.

original: Pañcapi upādānakkhandhā loko.
analyzed: upādānakkhandhāḥ loko
translated: The five aggregates as objects of clinging are the world.

original: Ayaṁ vuccati “loko”.
analyzed: ayam vuccati loko
translated: This is called ‘the world’.

original: Tattha katamā abhijjhā?
analyzed: tattha katamā abhijjhā
translated: Herein, what is greed?

original: Yo rāgo sārāgo …pe… cittassa sārāgo—
analyzed: yaḥ rāgo sārāgaḥ pe cittassa sārāgaḥ
translated: It is will for sensual desires, lusting for sensual desires, feverish greed for sensual desires,

original: ayaṁ vuccati “abhijjhā”.
analyzed: ayam vuccati abhijjhā
translated: This is called ‘greed’.

original: Tattha katamaṁ domanassaṁ?
analyzed: tattha katamam domanassa
translated: Herein, what is sorrow?

original: Yaṁ cetasikaṁ asātaṁ cetasikaṁ dukkhaṁ cetosamphassajaṁ asātaṁ dukkhaṁ vedayitaṁ cetosamphassajā asātā dukkhā vedanā—
analyzed: yam cetasikam asātam cetasikam dukkham cetas samphassa jam asātam dukkham vedayitam cetas samphassa jā asātā dukkhā vedanā
translated: It is mental disagreeableness, mental suffering, painful feeling derived from mental contact, painful feeling born of mental contact,

original: idaṁ vuccati “domanassaṁ”.
analyzed: idam vuccati domanassa
translated: This is called ‘sorrow’.

original: Iti ayañca abhijjhā idañca domanassaṁ imamhi loke vinītā honti paṭivinītā santā samitā vūpasantā atthaṅgatā abbhatthaṅgatā appitā byappitā sositā visositā byantīkatā.
analyzed: iti ayam ca abhijjhā idam ca domanassaṃ imamhi loke vinītā honti paṭivinītā santā samitā vūpasantā atthaṅgatā abbhatthaṅgatā appitā byappitā sositā visositā byantīkatā
translated: So this covetousness and this grief are subdued in the world, put to a stop in the world, put away from the world, given up, rejected, let go, abandoned, relinquished, and surrendered.

original: Tena vuccati “vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassan”ti.
analyzed: tena vuccati vineyya loke abhijjhā domanassa nti
translated: Hence ‘having subdued covetousness and grief regarding the world’ is said.

original: Kāyānupassanāniddeso.🔽1.2. Vedanānupassanāniddesa
analyzed: vedanā anupassanā niddesa
translated: The Description of Mindfulness of the Body is finished.🔽The Description of Mindfulness of Feelings

original: Kathañca bhikkhu ajjhattaṁ vedanāsu vedanānupassī viharati?🔽Idha bhikkhu sukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayamāno “sukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayāmī”ti pajānāti, dukkhaṁ
analyzed: kathañca bhikkhu ajjhattam vedanāsu vedanā anupassī viharati  idha bhikkhu sukham vedanam vedayamānaḥ sukham vedanam vedayāmi iti pajānāti dukkha
translated: And how does a bhikkhu abide contemplating feelings as feelings?

original: vedanaṁ vedayamāno “dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayāmī”ti pajānāti, adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ🔽vedayamāno “adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayāmī”ti pajānāti, sāmisaṁ vā sukhaṁ vedanaṁ
analyzed: vedanam vedayamānaḥ dukkham vedanam vedayāmi iti pajānāti adukkham asukham vedana  vedayamānaḥ adukkham asukham vedanam vedayāmi iti pajānāti sa āmisam vā sukham vedana
translated: Here a bhikkhu, when experiencing a pleasant feeling, understands: ‘I experience a pleasant feeling’; when experiencing a painful feeling, he understands: ‘I experience a painful feeling’; when experiencing a neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling, he understands: ‘I experience a neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling.’

original: vedayamāno “sāmisaṁ sukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayāmī”ti pajānāti, nirāmisaṁ vā sukhaṁ vedanaṁ
analyzed: vedayamānaḥ sa āmisam sukham vedanam vedayāmi iti nirāmisam vā sukham vedana
translated: When experiencing a worldly pleasant feeling, he understands: ‘I experience a worldly pleasant feeling’; when experiencing an unworldly pleasant feeling, he understands: ‘I experience an unworldly pleasant feeling.’🔽When experiencing a worldly painful feeling, he understands: ‘I experience a worldly painful feeling’; when experiencing an unworldly painful feeling, he understands: ‘I experience an unworldly painful feeling.’🔽When experiencing a worldly neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling, he understands: ‘I experience a worldly neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling’; when experiencing an unworldly neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling, he understands: ‘I experience an unworldly neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling.’

original: vedayamāno “nirāmisaṁ sukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayāmī”ti pajānāti, sāmisaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ
analyzed: vedayamānaḥ nirāmisam sukham vedanam vedayāmi iti pajānāti sa āmisam vā dukkham vedana
translated: When he is feeling a worldly pleasant feeling, he knows “I am feeling a worldly pleasant feeling.”

original: vedayamāno “sāmisaṁ dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayāmī”ti pajānāti, nirāmisaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ🔽vedayamāno “nirāmisaṁ dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayāmī”ti pajānāti, sāmisaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ🔽vedanaṁ vedayamāno “sāmisaṁ adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayāmī”ti pajānāti, nirāmisaṁ
analyzed: vedayamānaḥ sa āmisam dukkham vedanam vedayāmi iti pajānāti nirāmisam vā dukkham vedana  vedayamānaḥ nirāmisam dukkham vedanam vedayāmi iti pajānāti sa āmisam vai adukkham asukha  vedanam vedayamānaḥ sa āmisam adukkham asukham vedanam vedayāmi iti pajānāti nirāmisa
translated: When he is feeling a worldly painful feeling, he knows “I am feeling a worldly painful feeling.”🔽When he is feeling a worldly neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling, he knows “I am feeling a worldly neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling.”🔽When he is feeling a spiritual pleasant feeling, he knows “I am feeling a spiritual pleasant feeling.”🔽When he is feeling a spiritual painful feeling, he knows “I am feeling a spiritual painful feeling.”

original: vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayamāno “nirāmisaṁ adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayāmī”ti pajānāti.
analyzed: vā adukkham asukham vedanam vedayamānaḥ nirāmisam adukkham asukham vedanam vedayāmi iti pajānāti
translated: When he is feeling a spiritual neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling, he knows “I am feeling a spiritual neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling.”

original: So taṁ nimittaṁ āsevati bhāveti bahulīkaroti svāvatthitaṁ vavatthapeti.
